newsitem.title: USA: Blue-chip stocks buoyed by good inflation news.
newsitem.headline: Blue-chip stocks buoyed by good inflation news.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks soared Wednesday as unexpectedly good news on inflation calmed fears of another interest rate hike, but the rally stalled in the absence of support from technology shares.
At 1 p.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 41.62 points at 7,315.83 after gaining more than 75 points initially.
In the broader market, advancing issues swamped declines 14-8 on active trading of 291 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq Composite index, which is laden with technology stocks, was up just 2.44 points at 1,336.03.

The strength in blue-chips was ignited by news that wholesale prices fell 0.6 percent in April -- the biggest drop in nearly four years. Excluding food and energy, the Producer Price Index was down 0.1 percent.
It was the fourth straight month that producer prices have fallen and followed a 0.1 percent slide in March.
Analysts said the big drop in the producer prices lowered the odds that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates at next Tuesday's policy-setting meeting.
"The market reacted positively to the PPI but it is starting to look overextended, losing technology leadership," said Don Ascani, president of Global Market Strategists Inc.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond jumped 19/32, lowering its yield to 6.88 percent from Tuesday's 6.93 percent. The bond's price and yield move in opposite directions.

"The stock market is losing a little bit of steam," said Warren Epstein, head trader at Richard Rosenblatt Co. "Bonds are staying relatively strong and, given the bond market rally, I'm surprised the market's not higher."
He said if Thursday's consumer price report "confirms the PPI report, and the bond market rally continues, it raises the question of whether the Fed will raise rates next week."
Some analysts said they expected the stock market to stick to safe ground ahead of both the CPI report and the Fed's meeting next week.

"The market has had quite a rally in the past month and traders are more cautious near the 7,350 level," Ascani said. "Both stocks and bonds are due for a correction, and that might happen going into the Fed meeting next Tuesday."
Among technology shares, Intel Corp. stock was initially hit hard after Digital Equipment Corp. said it filed a patent infringement suit against Intel and would seek a "huge" damage award.
Intel stock was off 1-3/4 at 150-5/8 after falling as low as 146, while Digital was down 1/2 at 34-3/4.
Microsoft Corp. fell 5/8 to 117-1/8, while Cisco Systems lost 1/2 to 61-7/8. But International Business Machines Corp. continued to trek higher, trading up 5/8 at 174-1/4.
Micron Electronics Inc. shares extended losses, trading down 2 at 16-5/8, after the firm said its results would likely be hurt by price cuts in PC systems.
